NewsLine.NewsLineText: ECONOMY-GERMANY-ELECTION:German think-tanks, business see govt in a bind

body.p: By Nick Antonovics

BERLIN, Sept 23 (Reuters) - Germany's re-elected government of Social Democrats and Greens must quickly flesh out vague welfare reform promises to win back trust in Europe's largest economy, economists and business leaders said on Monday.
But with only a slim majority in parliament and no control of the upper house, the general view was that even if the government can come up with a bold programme, this may be hard to deliver.

German Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder's coalition appeared certain on Monday to scrape back into power with a parliamentary majority of nine seats. Schroeder said the Social Democrats and Greens would immediately begin talks to agree a new programme.
In the past the Greens, the clear winners in Sunday's vote, have been more outspoken in their reform demands and it remains to be seen if they will have more weight in the new-look Berlin.
Business leaders were quick to offer their own ideas.

"The election is over, now it's time to act," the HDE retailers federation said in a statement. "Tax cuts, reform of the social security system and liberalisation of the labour market are urgently needed."
Forecasting the economy would not even grow by 0.5 percent this year, Germany's Chambers of Commerce and Industry (DIHK) called on the government to draw up a "masterplan" of reforms.
"Economic development is in part dependent on psychology. The government has to give signals that will win back trust among companies," DIHK head Ludwig Braun said.

Schroeder's government pledged before the election to implement a series of labour market reform proposals put forward by a government-appointed panel, but left its intentions in the equally important area of health care vague.
SLIM MAJORITY BIG PROBLEM
"The problem is the slim majority, because there are many different voices within the Social Democrats," said Eckhardt Wohlers, chief economist of the Hamburg-based HWWA institute.
"Government in Berlin is going to be more difficult," said DIHK's Braun.
Klaus Zimmermann, head of the DIW economic research institute, said labour market reform must go beyond proposals drawn up the government-appointed panel, headed by Volkswagen executive Peter Hartz.
"What's been proposed up to now is not enough," Zimmermann said. "The government has to look again at cutting benefits."

The Hartz proposals included encouraging jobless people to take up full or temporary jobs or training places by threatening them with loss of benefits. But the benefits themselves remain attractive and effectively on offer for an unlimited duration.
They also included plans for the state development bank to offer firms cheap loans if they take on unemployed workers.

The new government is expected to propose draft legislation to implement the ideas as one of its first moves, although a number of measures will require approval by the opposition-controlled upper house to become law.
With two big regional elections pending in February, upper house approval is far from certain.
BUDGET WOES

DIHK chief economist Axel Nitschke and others said another problem for the government was that it had no money in its pockets to implement any reforms without busting European Union budget deficit rules.

Joachim Scheide, chief economist of Kiel's IfW institute, said maintaining a pledge given to its EU partners to get the deficit "close to balance" by 2004 would require 20 billion euros ($19.65 billion) of cutbacks over the next two years. Germany's federal budget is around 250 billion euros a year.
"In no case should this be achieved by raising taxes. That would be counterproductive for the economy," Scheide said, a view shared by HWWA's Wohlers.
But DIW's Zimmermann said it would be better for the government to negotiate a new medium-term budgetary target with the EU rather than slamming the brakes on spending.
"The goal can't be met by 2004. In the light of the most recent data I expect this will have to be postponed until 2007," Zimmermann said.
